column4: If my NVIDIA drivers cause my xsever to freak out, what are some possible solutions?
how does it freek out?
Primary Device is not PCI, "(EE) No devices detected" "Connection refused (errno 111)" and lastly "No such process (errno 3)
when you boot and get the grub menu choose rescue and there is an option there to reconfigure X
I've tried that.
rww might be right.. the stock drivers might not support sli.. check nvidia's site in the linux section for more info on that.
np.. you might end up installing 180.xx to get it to work.
I'm kind of a linux newb. could you explain 180.xx to me?
there is a driver on nvidia site for linux and the version number begins with 180.. the xx is for other version info. so a driver that's labeled 180.11 is older than 180.22 or .28..
I made the conversion 3 years ago and it's been a never ending learning curve.. once you learn one thing its off to another..
I missed it.. what card do you have?
Nvidia 8800 GT
and when you activated the restricted driver in System>admin>hardware drivers .. which one did you choose?
I've got two options: Version 173, and Version 177 (Recommended). I've tried both, and both resulted in me getting frustrated when X freaked out, and format/reinstall.

I have an onboard 8200 and neither of those worked well for me.  What I had to do was remove all programs referencing nvidia by looking in synaptic. Then installing the latest nvidia driver I got from their site.. there is a specific way to do it.. if you don't follow it it'll mess things up again..
I would not use envyng

I currently have no drivers installed aside from what's included with the ubuntu clean install, so I have the option of installing the nvidia driver from the site. Do you think you could walk me through it? I'm brand new to linux and the commands are all still very new to me.
so you havent' tried either the 177 or 173?
No. I've tried them both, but both of them resulted in errors I couldn't resolve in xserver, which forced me to format the partition and reinstall ubuntu.
ok.. do you have a gui running that you can manouver in?
yup
let me look up the link for the new driver. brb
would it happen to be NVIDIA-Linux-x86-180.22-pkg1.run? If so, I've already taken the liberty of downloading it.
yep that's the one.. ok.. go to System>Admin>Synaptic and "search" for nvidia
what ever pops up as installed that pertains to nvidia, uninstall it.
How would I do that?
installed apps will have the box colored/checked yes?
yes
should I also remove xserver-xorg-video-nv?
no.. that's an opensource driver for nvidia and good for a backup
smartdimmer, jockey-gtk?
let me reference my synaptic
no to both of those
Gotcha. Applying changes.
Done.
ok.. now the fun part.. 1st where did you save the download?
desktop?
Desktop, yes sir.
ok.. here's the thing. you can't install the driver while the gui is running.. so you're going to learn a whole lot really quick.. no worries though.. I'll walk you through it.
first open a termial.. Applications>Accessories>terminal
already open.
type .. sudo apt-get install irssi screen
and hit enter
already did that too. :3
really? wow.  ok  type screen
okay. I hit enter on the confirmation screen and I'm at a blank terminal with my prompt.
now ctrl+a then shift+s
Now it says 0 bash halfway down the terminal screen.
except you're still in the window with the terminal prompt right?
ok.. type irssi
okay. Got it.
should have made the terminal detach
did everthing pretty much go away?
I think so.. I made irssi detatch. I've got a whole terminal screen with the command prompt now.
now in the termial type screen -ls .. it will show you the screen session.. the first part of the name is a number . when you see that type screen -r <number> and it will reattach
if you have a scratch pad handy write the number down and "screen -ls" and "screen -r <number>"
got it.
also ctrl+a TAB to change from top to bottom..
starting to make sense?
ok.. write this down Ctrl+alt+F7 = gui
written down!

ok.. here we go.. first in the terminal do a ctrl+a d to detach.  Now what you going to do is ctrl+alt+F2 and when you get a terminal prompt then us screen -r <number> to reattach and then ctrl+a tab to get to the irssi portion and let me know you are there.
No GUI. Just a blank screen with cursor.
did you have one of the drivers still loaded in System>Admin>hardware drivers when we started this?
k.. go back to sudo nano /etc/X11/xorg.conf and change the reference to nvidia to nv
do I do this for all instances of "nvidia"?
hang on .. let me look at mine
only in the "Section "Device" " where it says Driver
Got it. Doing now
then when it's done Ctrl+o (that's oh) and enter then ctrl+x to exit. . now sudo /etc/init.d/gdm restart
Kay. .conf modified. Restarting now.
Now Ctrl-Alt-F7?
sure..
you'll loose irc but try ctrl+alt+backspace
I didn't lose IRC, nothing happened.
is this card an onboard card or seperately mounted?
does the machine have an onboard video card too?
No sir. I'm afraid not.
just a sec
I've got two of them in SLI configuration. If necessary, I can rip out my second card as it's not doing anything right now.
did you happen to notice any errors on install of the driver?
No sir.
But there was a few errors in the log.
Failed to load module type1" (module does not exist, 0)"
And "No devices detected"
ok.. try this.. sudo apt-get install build-essential
done.
then cd ~/Desktop .. then sudo sh ./<nvidia driver name.run . to reinstall
Alright done.
I'd shut down completely this time.. then start back up . sudo shutdown -P now
Alright. I'll be back in a moment with results.
yep
I got it working! :3
you around? I want to properly thank you!
